items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should be about delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, not just capturing leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose are critical, as they shape the quality and purchase-readiness of the leads you generate.
- The mindset should shift from what the business wants to collect, to what farmers genuinely need.
- Designing the right offer that solves real problems for farmers is more important than chasing high lead volumes.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, statistics, dates, names, or expert quotes. The overall recommendation is for businesses targeting farmers to prioritize creating valuable offers over just lead generation tactics.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this week were 4-8 degrees below normal, with lows regularly dipping into the single digits or below zero, including -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. The cold weather was accompanied by strong winds, creating wind chills near -20¬∞F on some days.

Precipitation was also very low, with 7-day totals ranging from around 0.5 inches in northeast Illinois to virtually nothing in southwest Illinois. January to date has been the 4th driest on record in Carbondale and the 10th driest in Charleston, with less than 0.5 inches of total precipitation.

The cold weather is expected to continue for at least another week, with most of the northern half of the state likely remaining below freezing for the rest of the month. However, a strong winter storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall to southern Illinois, with expected totals of 8-12 inches south of Interstate 64, and 3-4 inches in central Illinois.

The article also mentions the WILLAg.org radio programming for the work week ending January 16, 2026, which includes the Commodity Week panel discussion with Chip Nellinger, Brian Stark, and Arlan Suderman, as well as the daily Closing Market Report.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Farmers are now searching for information differently, moving away from traditional Google searches to using AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews, as well as mobile voice search.
- To cut through the "AI slop," brands need to focus on building brand authority and trust by providing real, trustworthy information to growers and producers.
- The way farmers find information has fundamentally shifted, and most agricultural marketers are still playing the old SEO game.
- Discoverability is now about ensuring expertise, content, and brand authority surface at the exact moment the audience is looking for answers, across every channel where they are searching.
- In the new AEO era, discoverability is about winning the citation, brand mention, and trusted source reference, rather than just winning the click.

The article suggests that agricultural marketers need to reevaluate their 2026 strategy and adopt an answer-driven content strategy, as well as amplify trusted voices, to remain relevant and visible to their audience.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Originating in Brazil's tropical rainforests, this system can work well for farmers with forested areas on their land.

Key points:
- Forest farming combines farming with forestry to create a self-sustaining, ecologically-balanced system. Common methods include thinning forests to grow understory crops, silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching), and alley cropping.
- Benefits include improved soil/water quality, carbon sequestration, habitat for beneficial species, and the ability to grow specialized forest crops like mushrooms, ramps, and syrups.
- Ideal lands for forest farming have existing forests or riparian areas with trees that can be managed.
- Farmers should inventory their resources, develop a forest management plan, and research niche forest products that can be grown and marketed.
- Regulations around wild-harvested plants need to be considered.

Overall, forest farming can be an economically and environmentally beneficial way for farmers with forested land to diversify their operations.

items.title: Jan 16 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: The second week of the year brought a fleeting taste of spring, with average temperatures between the mid-30s to upper 40s; 8 to 12 degrees above normal. Some of the more impressive daytime high temperatures this week included 69 in Kaskaskia and 68 in Carbondale. January to date has been 7 to 12 degrees above normal statewide, and has been a top 10 warmest first half of January on record in most parts of the state.…
items.summary:
Daytime highs reached 69¬∞F in Kaskaskia and 68¬∞F in Carbondale this week. However, precipitation has been below normal, with most areas getting 0.1-0.75 inches in the past 7 days. The winter season so far has been slightly wetter than normal in northeast Illinois, slightly drier than normal in central/western Illinois, and much drier than normal (top 5 driest on record) in southern Illinois. 

The warmer weather will come to an end this weekend, with highs struggling to reach 20¬∞F in northern Illinois and just above freezing in the south. Temperatures are expected to remain below normal through the first week of February. Light snow is forecast through the weekend and next week, but precipitation totals will be less than 0.25 inches.

The weekly Commodity Week radio program on WILL AM580 featured guests Logan Kimmel, Jim McCormick, and Mike Zuzolo discussing the latest agricultural markets and trends.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Key points include:

Objectives: Spray drones can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce field traffic, and improve access to hard-to-reach areas. Farmers should clearly define their specific goals before investing.

Regulations: Operators must have an FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate and Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application. State-level IDALS licensing is also required. Rules change frequently, so checking for updates is important.

Insurance: Standard farm policies don't cover aerial application risks. Farmers need chemical, general, and physical damage liability coverage specific to drone operations.

Equipment: Factors to consider include spray capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS/automation features. Local dealer support is also key.

Training: Proper training on safe operation, calibration, and weather monitoring is essential. Iowa State offers educational programs on compliance and best practices.

Adoption Approach: Farmers are encouraged to start small, compare results to conventional methods, and gradually scale up as they gain experience. Dry product applications can also be evaluated cautiously.

Resources: Iowa State University, the Digital Ag Innovation Lab, licensed dealers, and IDALS can all provide support for farmers new to spray drone technology.

The article highlights that spray drones can be a valuable addition, but successful integration requires careful planning and a thoughtful, stepwise approach. Staying up-to-date on regulations, safety, and best practices is crucial.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Winter sowing involves starting seeds in containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors, where the cold, moist conditions help the seeds break dormancy. This results in hardier transplants that mature sooner than they would otherwise.

The best vegetables for winter sowing include hardy greens like kale and cabbage, as well as spinach, onions, and leafy greens like chard and watercress. These plants can handle cold temperatures in their early stages.

For flowers, the article recommends sowing perennials like pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa. Many of these need a period of cold stratification, which the winter sowing method provides.

Specific varieties mentioned include 'Carex' cabbage for shorter maturation, 'Avon' spinach for mildew resistance, and different groups of snapdragons suited to varying light and heat conditions.

The article notes that winter sowing offers the benefits of direct sowing with less risk, and provides a natural way to break dormancy for plants that require cold stratification. It's an excellent method for farmers looking to get a head start on the growing season.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series meetings will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. The meetings are organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

The meetings will feature topics tailored to local growing conditions and challenges, including crop market and climate outlooks for 2026, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots and drones.

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, and late or on-site registration is $100. The registration fee includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available at each location for a separate fee of $30.

The meeting locations and dates are:
- Jan. 6 ‚Äì Sioux Center
- Jan. 7 ‚Äì Storm Lake
- Jan. 8 ‚Äì Burlington
- Jan. 9 ‚Äì Mason City
- Jan. 13 ‚Äì Estherville
- Jan. 15 ‚Äì Waterloo
- Jan. 16 ‚Äì Davenport
- Jan. 21 ‚Äì Ankeny
- Jan. 22 ‚Äì Atlantic
- Jan. 27 ‚Äì Iowa City
- Jan. 28 ‚Äì Le Mars
- Jan. 29 ‚Äì Carroll

According to Josh Michel, a field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach, the goal of the meetings is to "prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers."

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant and has lower nitrogen requirements compared to corn, and does not host the tar spot pathogen. Experts will discuss sorghum's production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Attendees will learn about forage sorghum research from Mitch Tuinstra, Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue. He will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality. Other speakers include Brad Shelton, Jason Tower, Nick Minton, and Jeff Jackson.

Venue tours will be available from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, and a dinner and bull test station tour will be offered from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
The Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113 in July 2024, indicating improved farmer sentiment despite declines in corn and soybean prices. The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

Key statistics:
- Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5% for corn and soybeans, respectively, from mid-June to mid-July.
- 34% of farmers cited high input costs as their biggest concern, and 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices.
- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than in July 2023.
- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than in July 2023.
- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.
- 72% of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same as in 2024, with the remaining respondents nearly evenly divided between expecting an increase or a decline.

The survey was conducted from July 15-19, 2024. The improvement in sentiment was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes, despite concerns about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are adopting an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn. The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology, is using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision methods to understand the dynamics of tar spot in corn.

The research is funded by two grants totaling nearly $1.1 million from the USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture. The team is collaborating with researchers from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

The researchers have developed a digital method called the stromata contouring detection algorithm (SCDA) to quantify tar spot in corn. They have tested the algorithm under field conditions and found it to be successful in quantifying trends, but some inaccuracies persist in fully automated scenarios. The team is now refining their training methods to improve the model's accuracy and performance.

Another research effort includes the laboratory of Purdue's Mohammad Jahanshahi, associate professor in the Lyles School of Civil and Construction Engineering and the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Jahanshahi and Cruz, along with their students, are working on a proof-of-concept data fusion project that integrates drone imagery and weather data to capture crucial details about the tar spot pathosystem.

The researchers aim to quantify and model tar spot epidemics in production-style fields using disease observations and drone-based imagery. Ultimately, the team wants to quantify and model tar spot severity by referencing and integrating imagery with spatial and temporal data.

The interdisciplinary nature of the project can place greater time demands on the researchers, but it also leads to better problem-solving as each person brings their own expertise to the table.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is hosting various sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering wool items, livestock-themed apparel, and more.
- On August 2 at 10 a.m., there will be an open wool judging and wool sale event in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place on August 4 at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held on August 4 at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- From August 8-11, 11 a.m.-6 p.m., the Taste from Indiana Farms event in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion will offer free samples of Indiana lamb.
- The annual Sheep to Shawl competition, where youth teams create a wool shawl from scratch, will be on August 18 at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.

ISA President Jane Smith stated that the association is "proud to bring the spirit of our industry to the fair, and this year we will bring it in the theme of 'Art and Nature,' showcasing sheep-related art from Indiana artists in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion."

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.

Purdue Extension will have a presence at the fair, offering interactive demonstrations and activities at the Purdue Extension Building on the north side of the fairgrounds.

Key Purdue Extension activities include:

Other Purdue events include:

The Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, including the 4-H Exhibit Hall, Expo Hall, Indiana Farmers Coliseum, and more.

Purdue University is a public research institution ranked among the top 10 public universities in the U.S., with a focus on affordability, accessibility, and the pursuit of new innovations.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The new NPM publication "Potassium Cycle" provides a comprehensive visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts, including:

- Sources of potassium, including soil minerals, organic matter, and fertilizers
- Potassium uptake by plants and movement within the plant
- Potassium losses from the soil through leaching, crop removal, and erosion
- Recommended potassium application rates and timing for optimum crop yields

The publication was developed by the University of Wisconsin-Madison to help farmers better understand the potassium cycle and make informed decisions about potassium management in their operations. It is available for free download on the NPM website.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Wisconsin winter wheat is progressing at a record pace, about 10-14 days ahead of normal. As of April 17, 2022, 26% of the winter wheat crop was in the jointing stage, compared to the 5-year average of 10%. Wheat condition is rated 79% good-to-excellent, higher than the 5-year average of 71%.

Experts Damon Smith and Shawn Conley from the University of Wisconsin-Madison recommend that farmers monitor their wheat closely for disease and insect pressure as the crop advances rapidly. They advise applying fungicides at flag leaf emergence to protect against Fusarium head blight and other diseases.

The early wheat development is due to warmer than average temperatures in March and April. This accelerated growth could lead to earlier wheat harvest, potentially impacting management of other summer crops. Farmers should adjust plans accordingly and be prepared to shift fieldwork schedules as needed.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Soybean fields may need replanting due to factors like freezing, hail, flooding, pests, and diseases. Before replanting, farmers should consider:

1. Yield potential - Replanted soybeans may yield 5-10% less than the original stand. Yield loss is higher for replanting beyond June 1st.

2. Maturity - Replanted soybeans will be 7-10 days later to maturity. This can impact harvest timing and drying costs.

3. Weed control - Replanting provides a chance to change herbicide programs and manage weeds more effectively.

4. Seed quality - Germination and vigor of replacement seed should be checked. Seed treatments may be needed.

5. Planting date - Ideal replanting dates are before June 1st in northern climates. Yields drop significantly for plantings after June 15th.

6. Stand uniformity - Uneven stands can impact harvestability and yield. Aim for a uniform 100,000-150,000 plants/acre.

Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist at UW-Madison, recommends carefully evaluating these factors before deciding to replant a soybean field.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:
- Farmers planning to use 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean in 2024 need to be aware of important updates and restrictions.
- The use of 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean will be prohibited in 2024 due to regulatory changes.
- Farmers should instead consider alternative weed control options for Enlist E3 soybean in 2024, such as glufosinate and clethodim herbicides.
- Rodrigo Werle, a Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison, advises farmers to stay informed about the latest updates and plan their weed management strategies accordingly.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any deadlines, names of people/organizations/programs, or locations beyond UW-Madison. The context is the regulatory changes affecting the use of 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean in 2024. The main impact for farmers is the need to adjust their weed control plans for Enlist E3 soybean next year. The article recommends that farmers consider alternative herbicide options and stay informed about the latest updates.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
